docs.lead_paragraph: NOW sitting atop Amazon.com's best-seller list: coffee. Not the book. The bean. Amazon introduced a grocery store last week, complete with sales rankings, customer reviews and recommendations. (For the record, customers who bought Froot Loops also bought digital pedometers. Who knew?) It is the 33rd product category Amazon has rolled out since it started expanding in the late 1990's, but for some it is the most puzzling, since it calls to mind some of the worst Internet business debacles on record.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Pequot Library in Southport begins its five-day book sale on Friday, there will be 147,000 books available, including a first printing of the novel ''Ben-Hur'' and a 1911 edition of the ''Encyclopedia Britannica.'' But those books, and many of the other 300 rare books there, are expected to be gone soon after the gate opens at 9 a.m. This is library book sale season in Connecticut, and book dealers say the Pequot event is the largest in the state. Dan Snydacker, the executive director of the Pequot, said about 12,000 people attended last year's sale and at least as many are expected to attend this year, including book resellers from around the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The online retailer Amazon.com reported a steep drop in its quarterly profit yesterday, while its sales continued to rise. The results showed the effects of higher expenses as Amazon offered free shipping and lower prices in response to heightened competition. The report caused a sell-off of Amazon's shares late in the day. The stock fell more than 12 percent, or $4.09, in after-hours trading, after declining 72 cents, to close at $33.59, before the report was released.

headline.main: Costs of Competition Send Amazon Profit Down 58%

docs.abstract: Online retailer Amazon.com reports steep drop in quarterly profits in response to increased competition; profit dropped 58 percent, to $22 million, down from $52 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 22 percent, to $2.14 billion, from $1.75 billion; total operating expenses increased 34 percent to $462 million, from $346 million; chairman and chief executive Jeffrey P Bezos comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EXPECTING A BLOCKBUSTER -- A heart drug still in the testing phase at Pfizer will be offered as a stand-alone pill, rather than only in combination with Lipitor, as Pfizer had first planned. Doctors had criticized the company over the combination approach to sales. [Page C1.] JAUNTING BY JET -- Entrepreneurs are betting on air taxis as a way to entice business travelers who are frustrated by jam-packed planes, endless delays and long security lines. [C1.] HONDA TAKES TO THE AIR -- Honda known for its small cars, plans to offer what could become the Honda Civic of the skies. The car maker said the HondaJet would be fuel-efficient, with twin engines and room for six passengers. [C4.] HOUSING CATCHES ITS BREATH -- The torrid pace of the housing market is slackening as prices level off and properties stay on the market longer. Experts say the housing industry appears to be evolving into a buyer's market. [C1.] TWO SIDES OF GOLDMAN -- A new focus at Goldman Sachs has exposed fault lines between the investment bankers who advise blue-chip corporate clients and the private-equity bankers who manage multibillion-dollar funds. [C1.] NEW UNION FRONT -- The Service Employees International Union has undertaken a drive to unionize more than 100,000 security guards nationwide -- a group of workers that in many cities is more than 50 percent African-American. The average pay for guards, says the union, is $8.50 an hour or $17,000 a year. [A13.] REGIONAL HANDSHAKES -- As global trade talks falter, regional deals are moving to the forefront. India, for example, is planning to sign an agreement with Japan and is talking with the European Union. The United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, above, said that America would also seek regional agreements and singled out Asia as a prime target. Countries like China and India, with fast-growing economies and a large middle class, are attractive markets for Western companies that manufacture goods or provide banking and insurance services. [C3.] TROUBLESOME BLIPS -- The Federal Aviation Administration has scheduled air-traffic controllers at seven of its busiest radar offices so that at least 70 percent of the controllers on a shift are always at their radar scopes, in effort to cut costs and errors. But controllers say they are working without breaks longer than rules allow, and their union has complained. [A14.] STRONG PHONE RESULTS -- AT&T and BellSouth, heading toward a merger, are continuing to add high-speed Internet customers, and AT&T's wireless group, Cingular, is still on top and getting stronger. Those bright spots, as well as the substantial savings they are wringing from the integration of SBC Communications and AT&T along with Cingular and AT&T Wireless, were behind the companies' better-than expected profit growth in the second quarter. [C6.] AMAZON PROFIT DROPS -- The online retailer Amazon.com reported a steep drop in its quarterly profit, while its sales continued to rise. The results showed the effects of higher expenses as Amazon offered free shipping and lower prices in response to more competition. [C7.] SLUMP AT NISSAN -- Nissan Motor reported a slight quarterly profit, but said operating income dropped steeply amid a slump in vehicle sales that the company called temporary. Analysts said the performance raised questions about the management of its chief executive, Carlos Ghosn. [C6.] YUKOS LIQUIDATION APPEARS NEAR -- The Yukos company's fight for existence neared its end on Tuesday when creditors rejected its plans for recovery and recommended that Yukos, once Russia's largest and most successful oil concern, be declared bankrupt. [C6.] JOBS SITE GETS A LIFT -- The new owner of the two major daily newspapers in Philadelphia said that it had formed an alliance with Monster Worldwide, the parent of the online jobs Web site. The resulting cobranded jobs site will be the first such venture between a big city newspaper publisher and Monster.com. [C5.] TEEN PEOPLE TO SHUT DOWN -- Time Inc. announced that it was shutting down Teen People, the monthly magazine that was a pioneer in the teenage category when it was founded in 1998. [C5.] ONLINE TRAVELING WITH CHILDREN -- Most people traveling with children know the drill and maintain order in the ranks. Still, tensions sometimes ensue. A report is at nytimes.com/business. POWER PLAYS IN FLIGHT -- At the Farnborough Air Show outside of London, the world's leaders in aviation gather to make both monetary and political deals. A audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Shares of United Parcel Service, the world's largest shipping carrier, fell sharply after the company reported an increase in second-quarter profit that missed Wall Street expectations. (AP) The DuPont Company reported a 4 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. Net income was $975 million, down from $1.02 billion a year ago. (AP) 3M's second-quarter profit jumped 17 percent and fell within the lowered guidance it gave about three weeks ago. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: BIG FAN: Seth Mnookin's new book, ''Feeding the Monster: How Money, Smarts, and Nerve Took a Team to the Top'' (Simon & Schuster), about the resurgence of the Boston Red Sox, lands at No. 8 in its first week on the hardcover nonfiction list. The team gave Mnookin, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair, unusual access to its inner workings; as he writes, he was given ''a desk at Fenway and an electronic passkey that opened almost every door in the park.'' Mnookin, who lives in New York but grew up in Boston's suburbs, called himself, in a recent telephone interview, a ''big fan'' of the Sox, but then pulled himself up short. ''Actually, to be considered a 'big fan' of the Sox, you've got to be the kind of person who schedules your annual vacation so you can watch the team play in South Florida,'' he said. ''I'm not quite that kind of fan. I've always loved them, but I'd probably been to 25 games before I began reporting my book.'' Mnookin's previous book was ''Hard News: The Scandals at The New York Times and Their Meaning for the American Media,'' about the fallout from Jayson Blair's fabrications. Interviewing ballplayers is both easier and harder than interviewing journalists, he said. ''Journalists are always apprehensive about being interviewed because they know that a story can change between its conception and its completion. Baseball players, on the other hand, are used to getting publicity all the time. It's a different type of anxiety for them -- they think it's a distraction, yet another thing they have to do.''

docs.lead_paragraph: 'Selective' Logging? Hardly When you think of logging in the Brazilian Amazon, what comes to mind? Most likely, clear-cutting by ranchers and farmers to create land for crops or grazing. But logging companies in Brazil also practice selective cutting, removing only some of the trees with the goal of sustaining forests (and timber harvests) over a long time. That's the idea, at least. But a new study of the Brazilian Amazon shows that much selective logging there is anything but sustainable.

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

docs.abstract: Gregory P Asner of Carnegie Institution of Washington conducts study on effectiveness of selective logging program in Brazilian Amazon; research, which uses high-resolution satellite images, finds that logging practices have not changed and large sections of region are still being deforested rather than preserved; is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; Lynn L Anderson of University of Illinois leads study that provides genetic evidence that white spruce trees did not die out in Alaska during ice age 17,000 to 25,000 years ago; research is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; National Marine Fisheries Service bans use of some fishing techniques such as trawls around Aleutian Islands in order to protect cold-water coral reefs discovered there in 2002; Peter Schiffer, Pennsylvania State University physics professor, leads study that finds technique of heating and cooling certain materials can allow greater quantity of material to be packed into same size container; research is described in journal Nature; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A better way to pack grains, logging in the Brazilian Amazon, protecting corals and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (TNT) NIGHTMARES AND DREAMSCAPES: FROM THE STORIES OF STEPHEN KING -- How does Mr. King sleep at night with his imagination running at such a clip? In ''Autopsy Room Four,'' Part 7 of this eight-episode horror series, Richard Thomas plays a man about to witness his own autopsy after a snakebite paralyzes him; Greta Scacchi (above, with Mr. Thomas) is the doctor who -- finally -- arouses his senses. At 10, in ''You Know They Got a Hell of a Band,'' the series finale, Steven Weber and Kim Delaney portray a couple on a road trip who can't find their way out of town. 8 P.M. (Discovery) EVERYTHING YOU NEED TO KNOW -- Last month, Gary Hall Jr., the Olympic gold-medal swimmer, successfully fended off a shark until his sister Bebe could kill it with a spear gun, but you may not be so lucky. This special, part of Shark Week, tells how to survive these predators if you don't have an Amazon at your side. At 9, ''Sharks: Are They Hunting Us?'' reveals whether humans have become these predators' favorite cuisine. 8 P.M. (13, 49) LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL 2006 -- Louis Langrée (left) conducts a concert fit for a king, or at least a kingly composer, in this 40th-anniversary performance featuring two of Mozart's ''Coronation'' works: the Piano Concerto No. 26, with Garrick Ohlsson, and the Mass in C major, with Hei-Kyung Hong, Sarah Connolly, Matthew Polenzani, John Relyea and the Concert Chorale of New York. Neither work was written for royalty but rather anointed when they were played during the 1791 coronation festivities of Leopold II in Prague, after Mozart's death. 9 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Is blood thicker than sweat? In tonight's episode, the top six go for the gold, including Heidi Groskreutz and Benji Schwimmer, cousins and former swing-dance champions. But there can be only one winner. 10 P.M. docs.lead_paragraph: In all healthy societies, the middle-class people have wholesome middle-class values while the upper-crust bluebloods lead lives of cosseted leisure interrupted by infidelity, overdoses and hunting accidents. But in America today we've got this all bollixed up. Through some screw-up in the moral superstructure, we now have a plutocratic upper class infused with the staid industriousness of Ben Franklin, while we are apparently seeing the emergence of a Wal-Mart leisure class -- devil-may-care middle-age slackers who live off home-equity loans and disability payments so they can surf the History Channel and enjoy fantasy football leagues.

docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTING in a volatile market, like the current one, resembles a bout with a runaway treadmill at the gym -- a lot of work, taking you nowhere, interrupted by occasional bursts of panic. But at least one asset class may provide a respite from this frantic trek: convertible securities, which blend features of stocks and bonds. In times of market volatility, they can thrive. Over the long term, they can offer much of the upside of stocks with less risk. A study by Ibbotson Associates in Chicago found that, from 1973 through 2004, convertibles returned an annualized 10.9 percent, nearly as much as the 11.2 percent of the S.& P. 500, but their returns zigzagged only about two-thirds as much.

docs.lead_paragraph: FED PAUSES ON RATES The Federal Reserve suspended its two-year campaign of raising interest rates, a long-awaited policy shift based on the hope that a modest economic slowdown will subdue inflation without much pain. The shift amounts to a bet by the Fed's new chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, above, on one of the most elusive goals in monetary policy -- a ''soft landing'' for the economy. [Page A1.] STOCKS FAIL TO REBOUND Stocks dropped for a third day on the prospect that the Federal Reserve may resume raising interest rates later this year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 4.29 points, to 1,271.48. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 45.79 points, to 11,173.59. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 11.65, to 2,060.85. [C11.] SEARCH ENGINES AS VOYEURS AOL over the weekend removed detailed records of searches conducted by 657,000 Americans and apologized for their release, but the records, copies of which continue to circulate, underscore how much people unintentionally reveal about themselves when they use search engines. docs.lead_paragraph: The other day a song popped into my head, just a few up-tempo instrumental phrases -- guitar, bass, drums and a Hammond B3 organ. I knew instantly what it was, though I hadn't heard it in at least 20 years. It was a passing moment from ''Martha's Madman,'' the first song on the first side of an LP called ''The Jerry Hahn Brotherhood.'' I bought the record when it was released in 1970. I was a freshman at Berkeley. It would have been easy to see the Jerry Hahn Brotherhood performing that year, though I never did. Its lone record was a sunny mixture of straight-up jazz with a blues spine, a music that wants the latter-day word ''fusion,'' though that word does so little good. Above all, it was a reminder of the eclecticism of the time. Audiences that would soon diverge found themselves packed in a hall together all night long, like one October weekend at Fillmore West when the Jerry Hahn Brotherhood shared the bill with Van Morrison and Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band.

headline.main: Caught in the Limbo of Vinyl: The Case of the Jerry Hahn Brotherhood

docs.abstract: Verlyn Klinkenborg, in Editorial Observer column, notes that he wanted to listen to 1970 recording by Jerry Hahn Brotherhood but he no longer had equipment to play vinyl LP, and lone album by jazz band was never converted to CD or DVD (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a truism that in a great many businesses, just a small fraction of the stocked items account for the bulk of sales. But will it always be this way? Chris Anderson thinks not. In ''The Long Tail,'' his best-selling new book, Mr. Anderson says the digital revolution is already making the big sellers less important compared with also-rans, particularly among cultural works, because the cost of storing and distributing movies, music and written matter has plummeted. The argument has broad ramifications because online ordering can obliterate some of the limits traditionally imposed by time and space.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning I woke up, went to the bathroom, brushed my teeth, decided I needed to take my vitamins and then removed two sleeping pills from their prescription vials and downed them with a gulp of tap water. Two seconds later I realized what I'd done, walked to the toilet, stuck my finger down my throat and tried to puke my guts out. Nothing. I'm 44 and I've never had to induce vomiting before. The fashion industry makes it sound so easy, but it's not. In the end nothing came up, and all day long I walked around wondering What happens next?

docs.lead_paragraph: While a wave of consolidation has racked the software world of Silicon Valley in recent years, John Chen, the chief executive of Sybase, has managed to stay under the radar and keep his company profitable. Starting in 1998, Sybase, a maker of relational database software, embarked on a mission to become a leader in the nascent market for mobile information. Eight years later, the strategy is still a work in progress, but it looks more promising. In a recent telephone interview, Mr. Chen talked about where he wants his company to go and how he has transformed Sybase's culture. Following are excerpts: Q. Why are you looking for new markets beyond databases? A. Since we're not the biggest player in the database market -- we're preceded by I.B.M., Microsoft and Oracle -- life is not as interesting if you just have to maintain a small percentage of market share.

docs.lead_paragraph: SETH FORD-YOUNG is a professional bass player who performs up to five nights a week with local jazz and rock bands and occasionally lends his talents to recording sessions for artists like Tom Waits. But these days he has an unusual second gig. As a senior music analyst at Pandora Media, he spends roughly 25 hours a week wearing headphones in an office suite here, listening to songs by artists like Sonny Boy Williamson and Memphis Slim and dicing them into data points. Is the singer's voice gravelly or silky? Is the scope of the song modest or epic? Does the electric guitar sound clean or distorted?

headline.main: The New Tastemakers

docs.abstract: Pandora Media seen as example of how technology is changing hierarchy of tastemakers of popular music as music fans learn to trust one another more than experts; Pandora analyzes hundred of traits in a song on a five-point scale; visitors to pandora.com can enter their favorite songs or artists and receive a stream of music with similar traits; reactions of Pandora users, its business model and effects on radio stations discussed; drawing; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Music fans are learning to trust one another more than the experts. No wonder they’re making the industry so nervous.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the leading purveyor of goods online, has started selling digital products, offering movies and television programs that can be downloaded and watched on a computer or portable video player. The move, which was expected, is the first major effort by Amazon, the Web's largest retailer, to sell downloadable entertainment. Amazon has at times moved toward offering music downloads but never introduced a music service. It does, however, offer some free promotional music files.

headline.main: New Service From Amazon Offers Downloadable Films

docs.abstract: Amazon.com begins selling films and television programs through its AmazonUnbox service, which can be downloaded and watched on computer or portable video player; will compete with Apple's iTunes Music Store and growing market, which includes Google, AOL, Movielink and CinemaNow; movies will sell for $7.99 to $14.99 or $3.99 for rentals; most television shows will be available for $1.99 per episode; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The move is the first major effort by Amazon to sell downloadable entertainment to compete with an array of online video retailers.

docs.lead_paragraph: I HAVE a theory about the F train. I think that people who ride the F train, which stops in the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, and is therefore the train of choice for dozens of writers, editors and publishers, choose their subway reading material very carefully. You rarely see the folks who get off at Seventh Avenue reading anything pocket-sized, and never anything with an embossed cover, or anything that's advertised on the train itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS details mounted last week about the flameout of Lee Siegel, the brash, preening cultural critic and, more recently, blogger for The New Republic magazine, the most common reaction among readers online and off was to cringe. In the Talkback section of the now-defunct Lee Siegel on Culture blog that is reserved for reader discussion (the blog was killed by the magazine's keepers on Sept. 1), the author, a polarizing but certainly well-placed figure in the American intellectual community, had insulted his detractors and posted rhapsodic comments about himself using a ''sock puppet'' -- that is, a pseudonym to disguise his identity. In this case he went by ''Sprezzatura.''

headline.main: Writers on the Web, Deprived of Masks but Not Their Pride

docs.snippet: Lee Siegel is by no means the first author to try to anonymously insult his detractors, and the careers of many who did so in the past outlived any scandal.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR most small businesses, competing on the Web is hardly easier than competing offline, where gigantic retailers with huge marketing budgets dominate. But for Amenity Home, a start-up in Los Angeles with three products, four employees and no marketing budget, getting noticed was a simple matter of word-of-mouth advertising, albeit in an unusual way. Late last month, an online shopper posted a photo of one of Amenity Home's $400 duvet covers on ThisNext.com, one of a new breed of Web sites that promises to connect independent-minded shoppers with hard-to-find products. Other shoppers copied the photo to their own blog pages, bringing the company some much-welcome attention, said Kristina de Corpo, an Amenity Home founder.

docs.lead_paragraph: WE were in the vicinity of the two-gallon tubs of mayonnaise when my wife committed warehouse club heresy. ''Sometimes I wonder how much of this stuff is actually a good deal,'' she said. With some items, neither of us had any doubt. Our local Costco sells an enormous hunk of Vermont cheddar cheese for just a little more than the supermarket charges for a modest piece of the same brand. Canned tomatoes are also a great deal, and if you buy diapers at Costco for a few years, you'll save enough money to buy an iMac.

headline.main: Distractions And Bargains Bought in Bulk

docs.snippet: Thanks to eBay and Costco, among others, a sizable portion of the retail economy is built on bargains that aren't really bargains.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Ecotopia,'' the edifying, entertaining and ecologically aware exhibition that opened last night at the International Center of Photography, means to get your attention. Near the entrance a looming, oozing black form threatens to engulf the show, like some leftover Valdez sludge trucked down from Alaska. This enormous dollop is the first of several that punctuate the galleries. All are made, appropriately, of a lightweight, petroleum-based insulation material called Tubolit, widely used in the construction industry. An environmentally sound replacement for asbestos, Tubolit is recyclable, but it also offers further proof that the dependence on oil, foreign or otherwise, ranges far beyond gasoline.

docs.snippet: At the International Center of Photography, an exhibition that portrays nature as magnificent, cute and enduring, while also increasingly dangerous and endangered, thanks to human indifference and exploitation.

docs.lead_paragraph: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod. But this summer, the company was unusually quiet. Apple watchers online concluded that something really, really big must be in the works. A wide-screen iPod! An iPhone! A hovercar!

docs.lead_paragraph: VIDEO mania is in full swing. Amazon is finally doing movie downloads. Apple is touting a new wireless gizmo to beam movies from laptops to TV screens. NBC is introducing a video syndication service that might pit it against Google and Yahoo, and it's joining the other big networks in putting its shows online for free with advertising. MTV is working with Google to populate its video content all over the Web. It is wholly unclear which, if any, of these or any of the dozens of other recent efforts that have been announced will break away from the pack, which is why many of them are couched as ''tests'' and ''experiments.'' (Whoever thought up this idea of Web sites forever being in ''beta'' deserves a prize as the spinmeister of their generation.)

headline.main: A Video Business Model Ready to Move Beyond Beta

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 1998 at a picnic in Silicon Valley, Eric Xu, a 34-year-old biochemist, introduced his shy, reserved friend Robin Li to John Wu, then the head of Yahoo's search engine team. Mr. Li, 30 at the time, was a frustrated staff engineer at Infoseek, an Internet search engine partly owned by Disney, a company whose fading commitment to Infoseek did not mesh with Mr. Li's ongoing passion for search. Like Disney, Mr. Wu and Yahoo were also losing interest in the business prospects of search, and Yahoo -- in a colossal corporate blunder -- eventually outsourced all of its search functions to a little startup named Google.

headline.main: The Rise of Baidu (That's Chinese for Google)

docs.abstract: Article profiles Baidu, Chinese search company founded in 1999 by former Infoseek staff engineer Robin Li with market value of $3 billion and which operates fourth-most trafficked Web site in world; while Baidu continues to gain market share in China, some analysts question whether it can withstand competition from Google and Yahoo, which posess superior technology and global work forces; photo; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Baidu is doing what no other Internet company has been able to do: clobbering Google and Yahoo in its home market.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE blue, yellow and coral facade of the five-star Hotel Saint Louis in Brazil's agricultural boomtown of Luís Eduardo Magalhães rises like an exotic bloom out of newly plowed soy and cotton fields that end in the sky of western Bahia. Americans and others can be heard discussing land deals at umbrella-topped tables around the hotel swimming pool. Land is cheap, and farming the surrounding cerrado, as Brazil's highland prairie is called, has transformed the country into an agricultural superpower. Charlie Munn, an American bird biologist who founded the nonprofit conservation organization Tropical Nature, goes to this frontier town 340 miles northeast of Brasilia to collect guests for a pioneering venture of another kind: an eco-tourism destination he helped establish in the neighboring state of Piauí, in Brazil's newest national park.

headline.main: Brilliant Birds and Bright Monkeys

docs.snippet: Brazil’s newest national park in Cerrado preserves the country’s most unusual wildlife, and is on the front line in the struggle to save perhaps the world’s biologically richest savanna.

The Amazon profile page is like a mini MySpace for authors. Minus the cleverly disguised pedophiles.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some years ago, in a covered market in the north of Yemen near the Saudi border, I meandered down a smoky, teeming alley, thick with the sounds and smells of Arabia. Something shiny caught my eye, and I turned down another corridor; but then a bolt of blue silk carried on a shoulder slid past, and I decided to follow. The man turned again and again in a labyrinthine route until one turn too many -- and he was gone. I tried to trace my steps back, back to where I had left my fellow Americans, adventure travelers on an exploration of Arabia Felix, but I couldn't find them. I tried to ask directions from shop owners and shoppers alike, but nobody understood English, and I knew little Arabic. At one point I realized I was lost, and a dizzying panic set in.

headline.main: A Chance At Discovery, But Only While Lost

docs.abstract: Richard Bangs Outdoors column discusses virtues of allowing oneself to become lost, a state to which most adventure travelers do not often succumb; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Investigators said Sunday that they believed the crash of a Brazilian jetliner with 155 aboard in the Amazon rainforest was probably caused by a collision with a small business jet. Rescuers ruled out the possibility of finding survivors from the Friday crash, the worst in Brazilian history. The investigators said they were basing their theory on information gleaned from interviews with those onboard the smaller plane, an Embraer Legacy 600 piloted by and carrying Americans, which landed on a military airstrip in Mato Grosso State after a sudden jolt severed part of the left wing. The plane had been en route to the United States.

headline.main: Midair Collision Probably Led To Brazil Crash, Officials Say

docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's embattled president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, finished first in the presidential vote held here Sunday, but fell just short of the majority he needed to avoid a runoff on Oct. 29. With more than 99.2 percent of the ballots tabulated early Monday, Mr. da Silva, his momentum checked by a last-minute corruption and ethics scandal, had 48.65 percent of the vote. The most competitive of his seven opponents, Geraldo Alckmin of the Brazilian Social Democratic Party, was running closer than had been expected, with 41.6 percent of the vote.

docs.lead_paragraph: Netflix, the popular online movie rental service, is planning to award $1 million to the first person who can improve the accuracy of movie recommendations based on personal preferences. To win the prize, which is to be announced today, a contestant will have to devise a system that is more accurate than the company's current recommendation system by at least 10 percent. And to improve the quality of research, Netflix is making available to the public 100 million of its customers' movie ratings, a database the company says is the largest of its kind ever released.

docs.lead_paragraph: It had been an uneventful, comfortable flight. With the window shade drawn, I was relaxing in my leather seat aboard a $25 million corporate jet that was flying 37,000 feet above the vast Amazon rainforest. The 7 of us on board the 13-passenger jet were keeping to ourselves.

headline.main: Colliding With Death at 37,000 Feet, and Living

docs.abstract: New York Times reporter Joe Sharkey offers first-person account of being passenger on plane involved in midair crash, and surviving; says he was one of seven people on private Embraer Legacy 600 jet whose wing was clipped by Boeing 737 with 155 people aboard while flying over Amazon rainforest; describes how pilots of his plane desperately sought airport to land, sending out Mayday signal and finally spotting runway of military base hidden deep in Amazon; describes hard and fast landing and sense of euphoria among passengers until they learned that Boeing's passengers and crew all died in crash; says Brazilian military inspector is certain that two planes were inexplicably at same altitude in same space in sky; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In a corporate jet flying 37,000 feet above the Amazon rainforest, I heard the three words I will never forget: “We’ve been hit.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Rescue workers on Monday found cockpit voice and data recorders in the wreckage of an airliner that crashed in the Amazon rain forest last week, killing all 155 people on board. A senior executive of ExcelAire Service, a New York-based aircraft charter and management company that had purchased the smaller jet in Brazil and was taking it back to the United States, was also being questioned.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brazilian judge ordered the police late Monday to confiscate the passports of the two American pilots who were flying the business jet that apparently collided Friday with an airliner. The airliner crashed, killing all 155 people aboard, but the business jet was able to land safely. The order is part of a judicial and technical investigation to determine whether negligence or disregard for air-traffic instructions might have led to the collision, above the Amazon rain forest.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOUSING COSTS GROW -- The burden of housing costs on people living in nearly every part of the country grew sharply between 2000 and 2005, according to new Census Bureau data being made public today. The numbers illustrate vividly the impact, often distributed unevenly, of the crushing combination of escalating real estate prices and largely stagnant incomes. [A1.] ASSESSING G.M.'S PROGRESS -- Is the turnaround at General Motors real? That is a crucial question that the G.M. board must consider when it meets today. G.M.'s biggest investor, Kirk Kerkorian, clearly disagrees with management's assertion that the turnaround is taking hold. [C1.] STOCK EXCHANGE PLAN DELAYED -- The New York Stock Exchange has pushed back a plan that would prevent brokers from voting their clients' shares in board elections when the stockholders have given no voting instructions. Catherine R. Kinney, president of the exchange, above, said that the rule change was not dead but that it was being scheduled to go into effect in 2008. [C1.] DATA FROM WRECKAGE FOUND -- Rescue workers found voice and data recorders in the wreckage of an airliner that crashed in the Amazon rainforest last week, killing all 155 people on board. Investigators continued questioning the American pilots of a business jet that Brazilian authorities say they believe collided with the larger aircraft in midair. [A10.] HIT IN MIDAIR -- Joe Sharkey, columnist for The Times, describes what it was like to be inside the business jet that was hit and forced to make an emergency landing in Brazil. [A1.] UNIFORM TEST AT WAL-MART -- Wal-Mart has begun testing a new look for its 1.3 million workers in the United States: khaki pants and a navy blue polo shirt, according to employees briefed on the plans. [C1.] FALLOUT FROM THAI DEAL -- In hindsight, the $1.9 billion purchase of a controlling stake in Thailand's dominant telecommunications conglomerate early this year by a group led by the Singapore government's investment arm, Temasek Holdings, was less than ideal, analysts and people close to the deal say. [C1.] HARRAH'S ATTRACTS OFFER -- Harrah's Entertainment, the largest casino operator in the world, said that Apollo Management and Texas Pacific Group had offered to acquire it for $15.05 billion in cash. [C3.] BLOW TO ONLINE BETTING FIRMS -- Companies that operate Internet betting sites and payment systems lost billions of dollars in market value after the United States government moved to criminalize the processing of online wagers. [C3.] ACTIONS OF EX-CONVERSE CHIEF -- After arriving in Namibia two months ago, Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology wanted in the United States on stock option fraud charges, transferred about $16 million to Namibia from Israel, bought a house and put his children into a local school, a Windhoek court was told. [C3.] INDIA'S ECONOMIC ZONES -- India is using privately run special economic zones as a partial solution to the extreme weaknesses in India's infrastructure: narrow, pothole-filled roads; erratic supplies of electricity and other utility services; and inadequate communication links. But opposition to the zones is mounting from political parties, farmers' groups and economists. [C5.] STOCKS FALL -- The Nasdaq composite index dragged down stocks as slowing growth among manufacturers heightened concern that the economic expansion is weakening. [C12.] TOO MUCH ANIMATION -- Analysts and industry executives have long warned of a coming glut of computer-animated movies. Now that time has come. With so many movies for audiences to choose from, some are failing to meet expectations or are flopping outright. For example, This summer's ''The Wild,'' from Walt Disney, proved anything but for moviegoers, bringing in only $37 million at the domestic box office. [C1.] NEW REAL ESTATE REALITY -- Without a white-hot market to drive the plot, the producers of ''Million Dollar Listing'' and other television shows about real estate now have to rethink their formats. [C9.] CONCERN ON AD RULE -- When an advertiser's relationship with its agencies goes sour, a breakup is often the best course for everyone involved. But some people in London's marketing world are now concerned that a new regulation could threaten this easy-come, easy-go existence. [C9.]

Investigators questioned the pilots of a business jet that authorities believe collided with the aircraft. A11 Rival Parties Lead in Bosnia Partial results of elections in Bosnia showed parties led by Haris Silajdzic, the Muslim who was prime minister during the civil war, and Milorad Dodik, the most prominent Serb politician, were likely to dominate the country's main institutions. A20 Shooting at Amish School A dairy truck driver walked into a one-room Amish schoolhouse in Pennsylvania and systematically tried to execute the young girls there, killing four and wounding seven before killing himself, the police said. docs.lead_paragraph: Brazilian Air Force officials on Thursday identified what they said were equipment breakdowns and confusion that probably contributed to the apparent collision of two jets over the Amazon a week ago. Investigators still have not determined how three systems failed: a nearly new, top-notch air traffic control network and an anticollision system on each of the planes. The crash killed everyone on the larger of the two planes, a Boeing 737. Its operator, Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes, said Thursday that it had found an error in its passenger count, and lowered the toll to 154 from 155. The smaller plane, though damaged, was able to land.

headline.main: Brazil Air Force Cites Faults And Confusion in Fatal Crash

docs.lead_paragraph: AIR traffic control was invented half a century ago largely as a way to prevent planes from crashing into each other, and mostly, it works. Twenty-five years ago, airlines began using on-board collision warning systems for those times when it doesn't. But on Sept. 29, two planes with some of the newest safety technology -- an Embraer Legacy corporate jet being delivered from the manufacturer and a Boeing 737 that was less than a month old -- apparently collided over the Amazon jungle in Brazil. The corporate jet landed safely but the Boeing crashed, killing all 154 people aboard.

headline.main: In Aviation, to Err Is Inevitable

docs.abstract: Recent crash of Embraer Legacy corporate jet and Boeing 737 in Brazil has prompted investigation to determine whether accident was caused by technological failure or human error or both; one thing is already clear: despite technology, collisions may be inevitable; anti-collision systems, which are standard on new planes, will become even more important as skies become more crowded, but some experts say goal is to reduce midair collisions because perfection is impossible; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Technology may reduce midair collisions, but it won’t eliminate them.

docs.lead_paragraph: STEPHEN KENNY remembers being in high spirits one evening after imbibing ''one martini or maybe three '' on his way home from work. He was in such a good mood, in fact, that he decided to get his girlfriend a present. ''I logged on to this luxury jewelry Web site and I bought her a pair of $1,500 earrings -- or what I thought were $1,500 earrings,'' said Mr. Kenny, who works at an intellectual property law firm in Burlington, Vt. ''Maybe my vision was blurred or I just missed a decimal point, but they turned out to be $15,000.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The electronic device for broadcasting a plane's identity and altitude carried by the business jet that apparently collided with a Boeing 737 over the Amazon last month was not one of the potentially faulty ones ordered repaired by American safety officials, the manufacturer said Sunday. The device, a transponder, is crucial to the functioning of anticollision warning systems. Brazilian officials said it had ceased working on an Embraer Legacy business jet before it had its encounter with the Boeing and resumed functioning afterward.

headline.main: Device on Jet in Amazon Crash Had Not Been Recalled as Faulty

docs.snippet: A review of the part numbers on the business jet that apparently collided with a Boeing 737 shows that the transponder was not recalled.

docs.lead_paragraph: MY 15 minutes of fame are about over, I profoundly hope. I will not be applying for an extension. So instead, let me share two major lessons I learned after six others and I inexplicably survived a midair collision at 37,000 feet in a business jet over the Amazon rain forest on Sept. 29 -- while 154 others in a 737 we apparently collided with fell to horrible deaths in a jungle about 600 miles northwest of Brasília.

The Chinese expressed their anger in unusually strong terms, saying the test was ''flagrant and brazen.'' Because of long negotiations to acquire right of way through residential and farm land, and through several hundred graves of religious significance, the project has not even started. Baker III, the Republican co-chairman of a panel reassessing Iraq strategy for President Bush, said he expected that the panel would depart from Mr. Bush's repeated calls to ''stay the course,'' and he strongly suggested that the White House enter direct talks with countries it has so far kept at arms length, including Iran and Syria. The skirmish was the third serious clash between American or Iraqi soldiers against members of the Mahdi Army in Diwaniya in less than two months. A1 Virginia Republicans Resolute In dozens of interviews in southeastern Virginia, a swing state in tight races for the House and Senate, many conservative Christians said that rather than discourage them from going to the polls, the scandal surrounding Representative Mark Foley only reinforced their reasons to vote for their Republican incumbents. docs.lead_paragraph: A profitless Web site started by three 20-somethings after a late-night dinner party is sold for more than a billion dollars, instantly turning dozens of its employees into paper millionaires. It sounds like a tale from the late 1990's dot-com bubble, but it happened yesterday. Google, the online search behemoth, agreed yesterday to pay $1.65 billion in stock for the Web site that came out of that party -- YouTube, the video-sharing phenomenon that is the darling of an Internet resurgence known as Web 2.0.

headline.main: Dot-Com Boom Echoed in Deal To Buy YouTube

docs.abstract: Google agrees to pay $1.65 billion in stock for YouTube, video-sharing phenomenon and darling of Internet resurgence known as Web 2.0; purchase price invites comparisons to mind-boggling valuations once given to dozens of Silicon Valley companies decade ago; question is whether YouTube will flourish or, like some other companies once considered Next Big Thing, soon fold; Google, with market value of $132 billion, can afford to take gamble, but question is how to put price tag on an unproven business; price Google paid may have been cost of beating rival bidders, including Yahoo, Viacom and News Corp; deal came together in matter of days after Google co-founder Larry Page and chief executive Eric E Schmidt met with YouTube founders Chad Hurley and Steven Chen and threw out offer of $1.6 billion and autonomy to continue running the business; this set off marathon of meetings and calls; YouTube is Google's first big acquisition after series of much smaller deals; photos; charts (M)
docs.snippet: YouTube, the darling of the Web 2.0. resurgence, fetched $1.65 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: HANGING from the pot rack in our kitchen are a variety of skillets and pans, some with nonstick coatings and some the kind you really have to scrub to get clean. Every once in a while when I reach up to grab a frying pan and my hand touches the nonstick one, I hesitate. Is Teflon coating bad? Should I not use it? These thoughts go through my mind, and then I usually just take down the pan that is closest to the size I need.

headline.main: Teflon Is Great for Politicians, but Is It Safe for Regular People?

docs.abstract: Alina Tugend Shortcuts column on whether cookware coated with Teflon is safe to use; holds one issue that can be confusing is potential environmental and health dangers posed by chemicals used in manufacturing versus risk possibly created when Teflon cookware is heated and fumes might be emitted; holds of particular concern is perfluorooctanoic acid, PFOA, also known as C-8, which is crucial ingredient in making of Teflon; says in 2004, DuPont, agreed to pay more than $100 million to settle class-action lawsuit brought by Ohio and West Virginia residents who contended that releases of PFOA from plant in West Virginia contaminated supplies of drinking water; says DuPont, seven other manufacturers and Environmental Protection Agency announced voluntary program this year to virtually eliminate release of PFOA into environment by 2015; Tugend says she will keep using her Teflon and old-fashioned pans, but will keep close eye as new information comes out; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The government says nonstick pans pose no health threat, but not everyone is so sure.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE rising sun is burning off the fog over Beluga Lake on a midsummer day in Homer, Alaska. A red-necked grebe ambles into her nest, and three chicks snuggle under her feathers. There is no sound except an occasional squawk or the distant hum of a seaplane. Watching the scene gently unfold on television, you can almost feel the water lap against your boots. This is ''Sunrise Earth,'' a commercial-free, hourlong program that showcases sunrises in spectacular locations from San Francisco Bay to Cerro de la Muerte in Costa Rica. The program appears daily on Discovery HD Theater, one of a growing number of high-definition channels (about 45 now). According to the Consumer Electronics Association, roughly 21 million American households have an HDTV, and this is the channel many owners turn to when they want to show off the hypercrisp resolution and booming sound of their new sets.

headline.main: The Sun Always Rises on HDTV

docs.abstract: Article describes Discovery HD Theater, high-definition channel run by Discovery Channel, which features nature documentaries with no narration, music, storyline or advertising; aim is not to entertain but to provide peaceful Zen-like ambiance; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A peaceful, plotless program to go with your coffee.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the world's oldest forms of commerce has finally gotten a foothold in the newest commercial medium. Online bartering, an idea with many proponents but few successes, is emerging as an e-commerce model, bolstered by a spate of new Web sites run by veterans of the e-commerce industry. And although these sites won't soon challenge Amazon.com or eBay, they are carving out a significant niche in what could be a highly profitable business.

headline.main: I'll Trade You My 'Titanic' For Your 'Spider-Man'

docs.abstract: Online bartering is emerging as significant niche in e-commerce; sites like DVD trading service Peerflix, CD bartering network LaLa.com, and book tade site PaperBackSwap show there is still place for physical media in world of digital distribution; businesses are not expected to challenge big online companies like Amazon, Netflix and eBay since they do not sell products and mainstream computer users prefer to purchase; industry is expected to be successful due to small, loyal user-base and high potential for growth; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Bartering, one of the world’s oldest forms of commerce, is finally gaining a foothold on the Internet, bolstered by sites where users trade books, albums and movies.

docs.lead_paragraph: The wild salmon still rush the dark Utkholok and other rivers here in Kamchatka, one of the last salmon strongholds on earth. They surge in spring and come in pulses for months, often side by side in run after run. All six native species of Pacific salmon remain abundant on this eastern Russian peninsula, scientists say, appearing by the tens of millions to spawn in its free-running watersheds. Even in October's chill they come: coho and a trickle of sockeye, mixed with sea-run trout and char.

headline.main: Salmon Find a Surprising Ally In the Rugged Far East of Russia

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN once-gritty neighborhoods that have become gentrified beyond recognition retain a few pockets that have not been worn away by ground-up construction and faux French bistros. On Orchard Street, just north of Canal, you can still be turned around by the visual contrast of a Hasidic community mingling in a world of Chinese signs, so the arrival of a new store in Manhattan offering California street wear, a nail salon, body waxing and Brazilian desserts can be viewed as totally alien or quite fitting, depending on your taste. Nina and Julia Werman, sisters from the San Fernando Valley and the owners of the store, called Valley, which opened at 48 Orchard Street this week, said it was the inherent mixing of cultures that made them believe they could add their own mixed messages to the block. Nina Werman, 30, a comedy writer who lives in the area and is a member of her Lower East Side community board, and her sister, a 33-year-old social worker, wanted to try new careers, but they had so many ideas they finally combined them under one roof.

headline.main: Mixed-Culture Zoning

docs.abstract: Nina and Julia Werman open store Valley in Lower Manhattan; store is comfortable place to shop for obscure designer labels that reflect sense of adventure; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A new store called Valley opened at 48 Orchard Street this week and the owners say it was the inherent mixing of cultures that made them believe they could add their own mixed messages to the block.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has a population of a million. The ''people'' there make friends, build homes and run businesses. They also play sports, watch movies and do a lot of other familiar things. They even have their own currency, convertible into American dollars. But residents also fly around, walk underwater and make themselves look beautiful, or like furry animals, dragons, or practically anything -- or anyone -- they wish.

headline.main: A Virtual World but Real Money

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST week, Google announced that it would pay $1.65 billion to acquire YouTube, a video-sharing Web site started only 20 months ago. At the same time, CBS announced a content-sharing arrangement with YouTube. This is the new world of interactive television, all made possible by fast broadband connections streaming video over the Internet. Television is becoming a two-way, interactive experience that offers viewers the digital agility of the computer, the display quality of a movie theater and content that can be summoned on demand. It will take us from what an F.C.C. chairman, Newton Minow, referred to 45 years ago as a ''vast wasteland'' to a vast interactive world of limitless content -- a long way from our couch-potato past.

headline.main: Spreading the Broadband Revolution

docs.abstract: Former Federal Communications Commission Chmn William E Kennard Op-Ed article contends that nation should have full-scale policy debate about direction of broadband Internet, especially about how to make sure that all Americans get access to broadband connections; holds that current debate in Washington is over 'net neutrality'--that is, should network providers be able to charge some companies special fees for faster bandwidth; says policymakers should rise above net neutrality debate and focus on what America truly requires from Internet: getting affordable broadband acess to those who need it (M)
docs.snippet: The nation should have a full-scale policy debate about the direction of broadband Internet, especially about how to make sure that all Americans get access to broadband connections.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Bette Gottfried, a 48-year-old regular at a Starbucks in Ardsley, N.Y., saw that her favorite coffeehouse was promoting a film, she wasn't immediately interested. ''At first I was leery,'' said Ms. Gottfried, dressed in workout clothes, wearing her hair in a ponytail and sitting near the window with her daily decaf mocha (''low-fat milk, no foam, no whipped''). ''I thought, 'Who are they to get involved in the movies?' '' Ultimately, however, she decided to take her 9-year-old daughter to see the film, ''Akeelah and the Bee,'' precisely because of the involvement of Starbucks. ''I trusted seeing the movie, because it was promoted here,'' she said. After all, she liked the company's coffee; she had already bought and liked several CD's it produced and sold, compilations of music by Carole King, Tony Bennett and Frank Sinatra. Why wouldn't she like a Starbucks movie? She did, and now she's considering picking up its latest cultural sales item: ''For One More Day,'' a book by Mitch Albom.

docs.lead_paragraph: AT FORD, BAD GETS WORSE -- The Ford Motor Company reported its worst financial results in more than 14 years and warned that its business was likely to worsen in the months ahead. Its new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said the automaker would require a full transformation in the way it thought about consumers and approached the American market. [Page A1.] HUMANE GROCERIES -- Whole Foods is preparing to roll out a line of meat products that will carry labels saying ''animal compassionate,'' indicating the animals were raised in a humane manner until they were slaughtered. [A1.] GOOGLE OFFERS TAILORED SEARCH --Google unveiled a tool that allows Web sites and blogs to offer visitors a customized version of its search engine, narrowing down its vast index so the results are more relevant for the sites' users. [C3.] INDICATORS LITTLE HELP TO G.O.P. -- Economic indicators are looking up, with gas prices tumbling, unemployment falling to its lowest level in more than five years, and the Dow Jones industrial index setting records almost daily. Yet Republican candidates do not seem to be getting any traction from them in the midterm elections just two weeks away. [C1.] I.B.M. SUES AMAZON OVER PATENTS -- I.B.M. filed two lawsuits against Amazon.com, contending the big online retailer has built its business on technology developed by I.B.M. [C1.] LENDERS COURT UNIVERSITIES -- With rising tuition and lagging government aid making private student loans a big and increasingly competitive business, lenders are courting universities with trips and gifts in hopes that they will steer students their way. [A1.] COURT RULES AGAINST THE TIMES -- A federal magistrate judge ordered The New York Times to disclose the identities of three confidential sources used by one of its columnists, Nicholas Kristof, in writing about the investigation of the deadly anthrax mailings of 2001. [A21.] AIDS AND LEPROSY LINKED -- With affordable AIDS drugs arriving in many poor countries, experts say a startling and worrisome side effect has emerged: in some patients, the treatment uncovers a hidden leprosy infection. [F1.] CITY CRACKS DOWN ON PIRACY -- Seeking to crack down on the sometimes-violent world of video piracy, New York City is beginning an aggressive campaign to hold building owners liable for illegal distribution activities on their property and to make the recording of movies in theaters a crime. [B4.] COKE BACKS CIVIL RIGHTS MUSEUM -- Coca-Cola said it would donate two and a half acres of prime land near Atlanta's downtown tourist district to a proposed civil rights museum that would hold, among other exhibits, the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. [A17.] POPULATION MARKETING -- In an era of rancorous debates about overpopulation and immigration, only a few marketers are paying attention to a major promotional opportunity that occurred last week when, according to the Census Bureau, the population of the United States reached 300 million. Advertising. [C3.] OUTSIDER TO HEAD WRIGLEY -- The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company named William D. Perez chief executive, the first time it has tapped someone outside its founding family in 115 years. The appointment puts Mr. Perez, left, in a position similar to his last one at Nike, where the founder promised to stay out of the way, then pushed him out after only 13 months. [C1.] STOCKS CONTINUE RALLY -- Wall Street extended its rally as investors grew more confident about earnings reports and as a decline in oil bolstered hopes for consumer spending. [C11.] AT&T PROFIT UP SHARPLY -- AT&T reported that its profit increased 74 percent in the third quarter, spurred by strong growth at Cingular Wireless and savings from the merger of the old AT&T and SBC Communications. [C11.] RUSSIAN CELLPHONE INQUIRY -- In the latest chapter in the tale of 167,000 missing Motorola cellphones in Russia, Moscow prosecutors say they are investigating whether 30,000 that were supposedly destroyed were, in fact, sold at low prices in the Russianh provinces. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. XEROX said quarterly earnings rose to $536 million, aided by a tax refund and strong sales of color machines and supplies for commercial and office use. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) SAKS INC., owner of the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, said its chief financial officer, Douglas Coltharp, and two other executives would resign next year as the company consolidates operations to New York City. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE UNITED STATES has requested that Namibia extradite the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, Jacob Alexander, who is accused of a scheme to pocket millions of dollars by secretly manipulating stock options, an American Embassy spokesman said. (AP) MEDCO HEALTH SOLUTIONS, a manager of employee prescription drug benefits, agreed to pay $155 million to settle allegations that it accepted kickbacks from drug makers and submitted false claims to the government. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) A FORMER printing-plant employee admitted leaking copies of the ''Inside Wall Street'' column from Business Week magazine as part of a guilty plea to insider trading charges yesterday in a case that the authorities have cited as a sprawling illegal stock-trading scheme. (AP) THE HOUSING SLUMP was a heavy burden for the economy in the late summer, a top adviser to President Bush said. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: Going into the critical holiday shopping season, Amazon.com said yesterday that it would slow its investment in new technology in a bid to start reaping the rewards of its continuing growth. Amazon, the huge online retailer based in Seattle, reported that its third-quarter earnings fell by more than a third, dragged down by heavy spending to get new projects off the ground, even as its sales rose 24 percent.

headline.main: Amazon To Curtail Its Spending

docs.abstract: Amazon.com says it will slow its investment in new technology in bid to start reaping rewards of its continuing growth; reports its third-quarter earnings fell by more than third, dragged down heavy spending to get new projects off ground, even as its sales rose 24 percent; investors welcome Amazon's decision to slow investment, bidding up stock more than 14 percent in after-hours trading; sales increased to $2.31 billion in third quarter, compared with $1.86 billion in period year earlier; profit declined 37 percent, to $19 million from $30 million year ago; chief executive Jeffrey Bezos comments (M)
docs.snippet: Amazon.com said Tuesday it would slow its investment in new technology in a bid to start reaping the rewards of its continuing growth.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street managed a tiny gain yesterday, enough to give the Dow Jones industrial average another record close, after the Federal Reserve stoked some fears of inflation pressures but implied that it was not intent on raising interest rates. The Federal Open Market Committee kept the nation's benchmark rate unchanged at 5.25 percent for a third straight meeting, but it noted in its accompanying policy statement that recent readings on inflation had moved higher.

docs.lead_paragraph: VIETNAM'S ECONOMIC GROWTH -- In the three decades since Vietnam has gone from communism to a form of capitalism, it has become Asia's second-fastest-growing economy, trailing only China's. And now, in the latest sign of its economic vitality, trade negotiators are preparing to put the finishing touches on an agreement for Vietnam to join the World Trade Organization. [Page A1.] MORE THAN HOME IMPROVEMENT -- Home Depot is displaying a growing willingness to stray from its single-minded focus on home improvement. The company's experiment with everyday products like gas, cigarettes and seasonal decorations exemplifies the belief of the chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, above, that Home Depot can not only survive a downturn in the housing market unscathed, but exploit the situation by plowing money into the chain. [C1.] SCOUTING FOR ONLINE TALENT -- One of Hollywood's top five talent agencies, the United Talent Agency, has created an online unit solely devoted to scouting out up-and-coming creators of Internet content -- particularly video -- and finding work for them in Web-based advertising and entertainment as well as in the older media. [C1.] CONCERNS ON RADIO PLAY -- In the last two weeks, songs from two record labels -- both distributed through Vivendi's Universal Music Group -- got a lift on the charts after a radio chain was paid to play the tunes in an advertising program that New York state officials say is used to trick radio programmers. The ad purchases come five months after Universal settled accusations that it bribed radio programmers with gifts like laptop computers and luxury hotel stays in exchange for airplay. [C1.] A NOD TO PREVENTIVE CARE -- With the number of uninsured Americans reaching a record 46.6 million last year, a handful of hospital systems around the country have done the math and decided that for many patients with chronic diseases, it would be cheaper to provide free preventive care than to absorb the high cost of repeated emergencies. [A1.] WAL-MART'S UPSCALE WOES -- The chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores, H. Lee Scott Jr., said the introduction of upscale products, like silk camisoles and 300-thread-count sheets, has proven ''choppier than it should be'' and the company has ''moved too far too fast'' with fashionable clothing. [C3.] PUBLISHERS THINK GREEN -- Media companies have published numerous articles on greenhouse emissions in recent years. Now, large publishers like Time Inc. and Hearst are starting to think about their own production of emissions that contribute to global warming. Advertising. [C3.] FINANCE CHIEF INDICTED -- Robert C. Trosten, the former finance chief of Refco, once one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, was indicted, accused of helping to hide hundreds of millions of losses. [C3.] EUROPE PRESSURES CHINA -- The European Union told China that it could face barriers to its booming exports like clothes, shoes and electronic goods if it did not work toward creating a two-way street for global commerce. [C4.] BELLSOUTH'S PARTING GIFT -- BellSouth, which is preparing to be gobbled up by the telecommunications giant AT&T, left investors a parting gift with news that its third-quarter profit jumped by almost a third, to $1.1 billion. [C6.] UNLIKELY USES FOR RICO -- Some corporations are using the RICO statutes, often associated with mob bosses and corrupt union chiefs, to attack other companies, including many that have headquarters overseas. On Monday, Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications company, became the latest company willing to take that leap when it sued Deutsche Telekom for $7.5 billion in United States District Court in Seattle. [C6.] BP'S PROFIT SHRINKS -- Third-quarter profit at the energy company BP declined 3.6 percent, slumping on lost Alaskan production, higher taxes in Britain and a sharp drop in gasoline prices. [C10.] DISPUTE OVER A COMMA -- A dispute between Rogers Communications of Toronto, Canada's largest cable television provider, and a telephone company in Atlantic Canada, Bell Aliant, turns on a single comma in the 14-page contract, and the resolution is worth 1 million Canadian dollars ($888,000). [C10.] AMAZON PULLS BACK ON SPENDING -- Going into the critical holiday shopping season, Amazon.com, the giant online retailer, said it would slow its investment in new technology in a bid to start reaping the rewards of its continuing growth. It reported that its third-quarter earnings fell by more than a third, even as its sales rose 24 percent. [C1.] MANY FIRSTS FOR NEW CHIEF -- Cynthia Carroll, a longtime executive at the aluminum producer Alcan, is to become the first woman, outsider and non-South African chief executive at Anglo American, the mining giant based in London. [C10.] NEW RULES AT N.Y.S.E. -- The New York Stock Exchange moved to bar Wall Street firms from casting votes on behalf of customers who do not provide voting instructions on corporate proxy matters. [C12.] SLOW DAY ON WALL STREET -- Wall Street wobbled through a listless session and closed mixed as investors awaited the results of this week's Federal Reserve meeting. [C12.] DEATH OF A RECORD STORE -- The liquidation of the retail chain Tower Records will have a severe impact on niche markets like classical music. According to one industry insider's estimate, Tower Records alone accounted for up to 50 percent of sales in the specialty genres. [E1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Oct. 9 about a malfunctioning anticollision warning system on a business jet that apparently collided with a Brazilian jetliner on Sept. 29, causing the jetliner to crash in the Amazon jungle, referred imprecisely to the precedent for such a collision. While the Sept. 29 event, if confirmed as a collision, would be the first in which two planes with anti-collision systems had collided in midair because of a system malfunction, it would not be the first collision of two planes carrying the systems. (Two collided over Germany in July 2002 after an air traffic controller countermanded the instructions from the system on one of the planes that had warned it to descend.)

docs.lead_paragraph: The lawyer representing the pilots of an American corporate jet that apparently collided with a Brazilian airliner on Sept. 29 said Friday that his clients were at their assigned altitude at the time of the crash, despite a flight plan that specified a different altitude. The corporate plane was a Legacy, built by Embraer, a Brazilian manufacturer. It apparently clipped a Boeing 737 operated by Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes, which crashed, killing all 154 people on board.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most customers at the Anthropologie store in SoHo come for the delicately woven knits and the ultrafeminine floral dresses. But these days at least some are coming for the books. Last Sunday the merchandise and books were coordinated with near-perfect precision. Resting beside a black sweater ($68) and a jet-black skirt with orange embellishments ($118) were copies of Annie Leibovitz's ''A Photographer's Life: 1990-2005,'' big and black and gleaming, for $75. A pop-up book called ''One Red Dot'' echoed a display of polka-dotted canvas sneakers, while another title, ''The Persistence of Yellow,'' perfectly matched a strategically positioned yellow knit sweater.

headline.main: Peddling Books, From the Carwash to the Boutique

docs.abstract: Publishers hope to revive sagging book sales by pushing their titles in unusual outlets, such as car washes, butcher shops, clothing boutiques and hardware stores; odd venues have become fastest growing component in many major publishers' retail strategies in recent months; new frontier is being explored after years of concentrating on big-box retailers and online retailers; total number of books sold outside bookstores is imposible to discern, but publishing houses know it has affected their bottom line; Simon & Schuster's special market sales, as they are called, have grown by 50 percent, surpassing total sales to independent bookstores; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Publishers are pushing their books into butcher shops, carwashes, cheese shops, even chi-chi clothing boutiques.

docs.lead_paragraph: The flight recorder transcript from the executive jet involved in Brazil's worst air disaster shows that its American pilots were told by air traffic control to fly at the same altitude as a Boeing 737 before the planes apparently collided over the Amazon rain forest, a newspaper reported Thursday. One of the pilots, Joseph Lepore, 42, of Bay Shore, N.Y., was told by the tower in São José dos Campos to maintain an altitude of 37,000 feet as he flew the jet on Sept. 29 beyond Brasília, the capital, on a northwest path to Manaus, the newspaper Folha de S. Paulo quoted the transcript as saying.

headline.main: Flight Recorder Is Said to Back American Pilots In Brazil Crash

docs.lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to an advocacy group, Target declined last year to make its Web site fully accessible to blind people with specialized screen-reading technology last year. If true -- and Target has denied the accusation in court -- it was a public relations blunder, and it may have been illegal as well. The National Federation of the Blind sued Target, contending that the company's inaction violated the Americans with Disabilities Act because the Web site is essentially an extension of its other public accommodations, and as such, should be easily accessible to people with disabilities.

headline.main: Do the Rights of the Disabled Extend to the Blind on the Web?

docs.snippet: A lawsuit claims Target declined to implement technology to make its Web site accessible to the blind. The ruling may decide if disability rights extend to the Web.

docs.lead_paragraph: Families of the victims of Brazil's worst air disaster filed a federal lawsuit yesterday against the operator and maker of a business jet that crossed paths with a commercial airliner, which crashed and killed 154 people. The families listed the operator, ExcelAire Service Inc. of Ronkonkoma, and the manufacturer, Honeywell International Inc., as defendants in the lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court. A spokeswoman for ExcelAire, Lisa Henrickson, said the company was preparing a reply. A Honeywell spokesman, Bill Reavis, said that the company would not comment because it had not seen the lawsuit. The lawsuit, which seeks unspecified damages, said the Sept. 29 crash resulted when the executive jet, flown by two New York pilots, collided with a Boeing 737 operated by Gol Airlines, which plunged into the Amazon rainforest. Although the crash damaged the smaller jet's wing and tail, it landed safely.

docs.lead_paragraph: MIDWAY through the acknowledgments in his 21st novel, ''Wild Fire'' -- which reached the No. 3 spot at Amazon by lunchtime on Nov. 6, the day it was released -- Nelson DeMille tells his readers that he is following a trend among writers to thank famous people for ''inspiration, non-existent assistance, and/or some casual reference to the author's work.'' He proceeds to extend his gratitude to the former Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen, for once saying something nice about his books; to Paris Hilton, for belonging to a family whose hotel chain carries them in gift shops; and to Don DeLillo and Joan Didion, whose names appear before and after his in almanacs and lists of American writers. ''Thanks,'' he writes, ''for being there, guys.'' No one visiting Amazon will learn that customers who bought, say, ''Night Fall,'' Mr. DeMille's fictionalized account of the story behind the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, also bought ''White Noise'' or ''Salvador.'' Though he is a writer of topical political thrillers, Mr. DeMille is not the kind of genre writer with whom the literary-minded tend to experiment. His success during the past three decades, however, has marched on unimpeded. At 63, he is among the best-selling writers in recent history, with more than 30 million copies of his books in print worldwide.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early morning is the finest part of the day in Amazonia. The air is sweet and dewy. The temperature is as cool as it will get for the next 24 hours. Freshwater dolphins breach the calm surface water. An assortment of tropical birds calls raucously. And, each day, a pink-to-orange rising sun ball bathed the rain forest in warm mellow colors. On this morning, the fourth on a weeklong trip, Darrell Vore and I are headed up the Rio Igapo-açu, the ''river of the big-flooded forest,'' and a three-times-removed tributary to the mighty Madeira River. We are a 25-hour boat ride from Autazes, the nearest city.

headline.main: Navigating the Amazon Region in Search of a Big One

docs.lead_paragraph: THE RIVER OF DOUBT: Theodore Roosevelt's Darkest Journey, by Candice Millard. (Broadway, $14.95.) After losing his third-party bid to take back the presidency in 1912, Theodore Roosevelt joined the Brazilian explorer Col. Cândido Rondon on a survey of the Rio da Dúvida, an uncharted capillary of the Amazon. In this vibrant retelling of the expedition, Millard, a former writer and editor for National Geographic, records the incredible hardships that the travelers endured --starvation, Indian attack, disease, drowning and the loss of their boats and supplies. She also explains the evolution of the Amazon and the tectonic shifts that separated South America from Africa. In the Book Review, Bruce Barcott said Millard ''combines high adventure well told with dazzling passages of nature writing that illuminate the darkest, steamiest sections of the Amazon forest.''

docs.lead_paragraph: For fashionistas in lower tax brackets, reproducing the latest hip look from Lindsay Lohan or Paris Hilton can mean endless clicking through online retail sites and hit-or-miss searches on Google or shopping engines like Shopping.com. Now a new search site, Like.com, offers a shortcut for the budget-minded wannabe. The site, rolled out last week, relies on artificial intelligence technology to search images on the Web, and serve up goods for sale that visually match items on a shopper's wish list.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bored with the same family photos on the fridge every day? Digital picture frames let you create slide shows of your loved ones that rotate through the frame's L.C.D. screen. Getting those pictures into the frame generally requires a direct connection to a computer, or the insertion of a flash memory card filled with photos. A new model from a British company called A Living Picture untethers the frame from all physical storage media, letting you download pictures to the frame over a Wi-Fi connection, wherever it sits in the house.

Yesterday afternoon it jumped to No. 143, according to Sean Sundwall, an Amazon spokesman. The fiction winner, ''The Echo Maker'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) by Richard Powers, moved from No. 1,031 on Wednesday afternoon to No. 61 yesterday. Also winning National Book Awards were M. T. Anderson for ''The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing, Traitor to the Nation, Volume One: The Pox Party'' (Candlewick Press), in the young people's literature category, and in poetry, Nathaniel Mackey for ''Splay Anthem'' (New Directions Publishing). JULIE BOSMAN

The men are distant cousins.
